lines.text: I know why you wanted to see me - *she* sent you.
She? Mrs. Paradine doesn't even know that I'm here. She had nothing to do with it.
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: It seems I'm wrong then.
Why would she send me?
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: She might have her reasons.
I don't know what they might be.
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: But perhaps you don't know her as I do.
Mrs. Paradine is my client. I know her as her lawyer, that's sufficient for me.
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: You may not think it, but you're on the wrong side, sir, and I tell you so.
What so you mean exactly by that? You'd better make yourself clear.
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: Excuse me, sir. You have only known Mrs. Paradine since she is in prison. Is it not so?
Yes.
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: Then how can you know her? If you did, I should not need to tell you that only Almighty God or the black Devil himself knows what's going on in that head of hers.
I won't hear anything more against her.
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: I know what I'm talking about; what I say is true. I know her. And I will tell you one thing more, I will tell you about Mrs. Paradine - she's bad, bad to the bone! If ever there was an evil woman, she is one.
Would you mind getting out of here? I don't want any dirty, lying sneaks in my room. Get out!
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: Very good, sir, as you wish.

[leaving]
If you would allow me, sir, I'm very sorry for you - and God help you.

I have nothing more to say to you, Mr. Keane. I loved Andre Latour... and you murdered him. My life is finished; it is you yourself who have finished it. My only comfort is the hatred and contempt I feel for you!

[about Mrs. Paradine]
What's she really like?
Fascinating, fascinating. I'm an old ruin, but she certainly brings my pulse up a beat or two.
I do not like to be interrupted in the middle of an insult.
Well, nice people don't go murdering other nice people.
She had patience. She could wait. This was, indeed, no ordinary woman.
lines.character: Sir Joseph, Counsel for the Prosecution

lines.text: You are not to destroy him - if you do, I shall hate you as I've never hated a man.
It was she who dragged us both down. I hated every moment with her, but God forgive me, I couldn't help myself!
Have you ever realized what a lot you can learn from photographs?
The social footsteps of time.
Does the name of Margaret Wells convey anything to you?
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text:
[hesitating]
Yes, sir.
What does that name convey to you?
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: [Latour doesn't respond]

Well, I must try to help your memory. I put it to you that some years ago you were engaged to Margaret Wells of Three Rivers, Quebec; that on your wedding day she left you at the church door and went off with a saddler named Richard Truton.
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: That is finished! That is in the past!
Your question may be relevant, Mr Keane; its relevance escapes me.
M'lord, I submit that the witness has shown, in his evidence and also in his behavior, an almost pathological bias against, not only my client, but against all women.
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: I may be stupid, but I fail to understand what this jilting has to do with the case; after seeing the witness and observing his appearance and bearing, I should be inclined to regard the young lady's conduct as pathological, not his.
Is anyone living at the hall now?
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: Only the caretaker, Mrs. Clarr - maybe Andre's back from London now. They say he knows more about the poor Colonel's death than he would tell. He's a queer one, all right.
In what way?
lines.character: Anthony Keane, Counsel for the Defense

lines.text: Oh, I don't know. He keeps himself to himself - perhaps that's because he's foreign. They never do seem quite the same, do they, sir?
Tony's torn him to pieces - it was horrible.
But darling, you've got to remember, its Tony's job.
I've just been informed that the witness Latour has done away with himself.
lines.character: Sir Joseph, Counsel for the Prosecution

lines.text: [first title card]
the recent past.
[first lines]
Dinner will be ready in fifteen minutes, mum.
Thank you, Lakin.

[about Mrs. Paradine]
I've been of the opinion that she was a woman of very low estate and very easy virtue.
The best men always end up with the worst women.

[Rhetorically]
Who needs pity more than a woman who's sinned?

[about Mrs. Paradine]
You'll find her a strange woman with an almost mystical charm.
